article.description: With Alabama locked in a one-point game at halftime, Chuck Davis had one thing to tell his teammates.
article.headline: 'In the zone,' Davis scores 21 points
article.linkText: 'Bama upsets Badgers for sixth straight victory
article.story: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. (AP) -- With Alabama locked in a one-point game at halftime, Chuck Davis had one thing to tell his teammates. "Chuck just asked for the ball," Earnest Shelton said. "He told us he didn't think they could guard him in the post." Davis proved himself correct, scoring 15 of his career-high 21 points in the second half to help Alabama to a 71-56 victory over Wisconsin (No. 15 ESPN/USA Today, No. 18 AP) on Tuesday night. "I was in the zone," said Davis, who scored 10 points during a 16-7 run that helped the Crimson Tide (8-2) build a double-digit lead it kept for good. "I felt like every shot I threw up was going in, and I just got to get the ball when I feel like that." Shelton added 20 points and Kennedy Winston had 12 to help the Tide win its sixth in a row. Devin Harris scored 22 points to lead Wisconsin (8-2) but was held to just 2-of-6 shooting in the second half. Four of his seven points after halftime came with Alabama comfortably ahead. "I got a lot of open looks off the zone in the first half," Harris said. "In the second half, they pretty much face-guarded me the whole time and limited my touches." Antoine Pettway and Emmett Thomas provided much of that tight defense. Pettway managed only two points and fouled out in the process but held Harris in check as Alabama made its decisive run. Wisconsin trailed 33-32 at halftime, then cut the Tide's lead to 41-38 on a layup by Boo Wade with 15:33 to play. But the Badgers didn't hit another field goal until Harris finally drilled a 3-pointer 6{ minutes later. In the meantime, Davis and Winston took over offensively. Davis scored Alabama's next 10 points, giving the Tide a 51-40 lead. Then it was Winston's turn. The sophomore had made only one of his first seven shots, but he scored eight straight points as Alabama went up 59-43. Wisconsin would get no closer than 13 the rest of the way. "I really liked our defense," Tide coach Mark Gottfried said. "I thought we did a good job pressuring the ball. "(The Badgers) run you through the grinder every trip down the floor and our guys sustained their defense, which is what I really like." Wisconsin played without the injured Alando Tucker, who had averaged 19.5 points in two starts this season and was the team's second-leading scorer. That forced coach Bo Ryan to look further than usual down his bench in what he called the most physical game he's seen in three seasons with the Badgers. "Physical meaning there's a lot more bumping, a lot more checking," Ryan said "Some nights, it's certain things and other nights it isn't, and you've just got to be tough enough to play through it." Alabama held Wisconsin to just 35 percent shooting and eight rebounds in the second half. The Tide shot 52 percent for the game.
